headline.kicker: EGYPT: DEPENDENCE ON IMPORTS OF FOOD
headline.main: A World to Feed 15th article of a series appearing; periodically.

byline.original: By ANN CRITTENDEN, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The roads leading out of the capital north toward the tiny towns in the Nile delta bump past neat, square fields of cotton and rice, occasional processions of camels and buffaloes turning waterwheels in the shade of huge billboards for Pepsi and Toyotas. Like the well-stocked produce markets in Cairo, the rural scene conveys an impression of abundance. But in fact the Egyptian fellaheen, or peasants, produce only a little more than half the food consumed in the country. Egyptians, more than almost any other people in the developing world, are dependent upon foreign countries and food aid for their daily bread. The Egyptian Government, also to a degree unknown almost anywhere else, subsidizes the prices of that food from abroad, to make it available to the restless and potentially explosive population in the cities. The Government keeps food prices so low that bread is actually fed to sheep and chickens, according to residents here. This strategy of cheap food is a cornerstone of national policy and a key to political stability in Egypt. Wheat and Peace ''You have to buy domestic peace in some way, and they buy it through wheat,'' Harold Ackerman, of the Ford Foundation office in Cairo, said in a recent interview.
